Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The legacy of transience: Understanding dynamic landscape adjustment following mountain uplift in two CZO field areas
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will further geologic understanding of tectonic history and its imprint on the current landscape. Understanding landscape response to tectonics can inform land management decisions and aid in quantifying hazard risk. The project focuses on two specific landscapes from NSF supported Critical Zone Observatories (CZO) and leverages existing data and resources from these two sites. The project combines field work, laboratory analysis, and modeling. Project outcomes will benefit the Earth science research community as well as policy makers. Landlab, the computational model that will be used and further developed in this project, will be made available through the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) website. The project will also provide a K-12 training module and Landlab numerical modeling exercises for undergraduate and graduate students.

This study explores the unique signature of landscape adjustment following a change in tectonics in two different settings: South Fork Eel River, Northern California, USA and Rio Icacos, in Northeastern Puerto Rico. In both field areas, the current topography indicates that part of the landscape has not yet adjusted to a past or ongoing tectonic disturbance. The overall objective of the project is to understand and quantify the temporal evolution of the entire landscape, focusing specifically on the transformation of the relict topography to adjusted topography in these two field sites. A framework to interpret tectonic history of landscapes based on distribution of relict and adjusted topography will be developed through a combination of field work, cosmogenic nuclide geochronology, and landscape evolution modeling. Field work will include mapping relict parts of the landscape and quantifying morphologic features that vary between the adjusted and relict topography. Field observations will be combined with analyses of digital topographic maps. This work will allow future studies to easily identify relict topography in other landscapes. Geochemical techniques will be used to measure the spatially averaged denudation rate across the two landscapes. Numerical experiments using Landlab will be performed to understand how the tectonic history is expressed in the topography and denudation rate patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project significantly advanced our understanding of how rivers evolve following climatic and tectonic perturbations. We quantified how natural landscapes respond to uplift and these data can be used to inform land management decisions and aid in quantifying hazard risk. The project combined field work, new ages of landforms, geochemical analyses, topographic analyses, and numerical modeling to compare two specific landscapes from NSF supported Critical Zone Observatories (CZO). We found that the type of rock underlying the river channels and hillslopes plays a critical role in how fast landscapes erode and how fast rivers incise through the rock itself. We developed new components in Landlab, the computational landscape evolution model, and made them available through the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) website. The project provided K-12 education and Landlab numerical modeling exercises for undergraduate and graduate students as well as an installation of a new "Augmented Reality Sandbox" public display that educates 460,000 visitors annually. This grant funded the individual training of three graduate students, two undergraduate students and two postdoctoral researchers. Five of seven of these trainees were women or under-represented minorities, which built new pathways and opportunities for their future scientific careers. 


This study explored the signature of landscape adjustment following a change in tectonics in two different settings: South Fork Eel River, Northern California, USA and Rio Icacos, in Northeastern Puerto Rico. In both field areas, the current topography indicates that part of the landscape has not yet adjusted to a past or ongoing tectonic disturbance. We quantified the temporal evolution of each landscape, focusing specifically on the transformation of the relict topography to adjusted topography in these two field sites. 


Our findings from the South Fork Eel River, in northern California indicate that incision initiated ~100,000 years ago. We interpret the ages of alluvial sediments on terrace treads along the main channel to all be roughly uniform. This implies that erosion rates increased uniformly along the main channel downstream of the modern knickpoint, possibly due to a change in climate. The climatic perturbation increased erosion rates in channels only above a threshold drainage area. As a result, erosion rates initially increased in the main channel only, lowering relative baselevel on the tributaries to the mainstem downstream of the knickpoint. At some point, the tributary junctions with the mainstem steepened enough to trigger increased erosion and upstream migrating knickpoints in the tributaries. The result of this "two-phase" knickpoint creation is that erosion rates doubled as knickpoints migrated through the landscape. 


Close inspection of knickpoints shows that those in tributary watersheds underlain by melange have migrated further upstream to higher elevations in comparison with knickpoints in sandstone and mudstone watersheds. Further topographic analyses suggest that fluvial erosion rates are more non-linear with slope, or the exponent on slope in the stream power equation is greater, in the melange watersheds. Numerical modeling in Landlab focused solely on tributary evolution supports the idea that fluvial incision in the melange watersheds is more non-linear with slope than in comparison with the sandstone and mudstone watersheds. We collected grain size data in the field, because we hypothesized that the difference in fluvial processes between the different watersheds was a result of different grain size distributions. However, the data are inconclusive.


Hillslopes also responded as fluvial incision increased. The frequency of mass movements decrease upstream in the main steam channel, with mass movements having a larger impact on the adjusted lower basin of the South Fork Eel River, than the relict upper basin. 


In Puerto Rico, we find many similarities to the N. California watershed despite the fact that the landscape is responding to a tectonic perturbation that occurred 4 million years ago: erosion rates also double downstream of knickpoints, or waterfalls, and the hillslopes also respond to the new baselevel with the greatest number of landslides below the relict landscape. In both field sites, the rock type exerts a strong control on river and hillslope form and stream incision processes.  This work will allow future studies to easily identify relict topography in other landscapes and through model integration of the field data, will help predict how landscapes might change over time.
